messages.content: Despite having used this card a lot, I honestly don't exactly know what to say about it
While it's not great as a damage card in the early game, its gem multiplication makes it pretty darn good overall

pretty good starting card 3/4ths of the time. Having to start with brace gem is pretty rough though, i've been experimenting with skipping to put a gem in if the starter gem is sapphire; that strategy isnt that bad although your relying a lot on your early combats giving you both a socket and 2 other gems pretty quickly. Getting what is effectively double value from one gem makes this card a pretty good choice to put onix inside, card draw or energy are also quite good.
HAHA <EMERALD> + <ONYX> GO BRRRRRRRRRRRR

swadali skadrit this card is now a canrtip

2 cost brace 16
back when aquamarine was common, I made Dex+Ward twin slam probably the most out of any twin slam combo, as it's Dash+
same
it also scales twice with dex and twice with str
now that it's not, I find myself waiting to upgrade twin slam until I find a good second gem instead of pre upgrading in preparation of a socket
you can also pair the vuln/flex gems for some pretty insane early damage output
part of that is ascending the spire instead of descending, but if I was descending I'd very heavily consider switching to Curl Up upgrade first

minor question:
do you think dex ward or str shiv is better
absolutely dex ward
but only because str is better in other socketed cards
shiv is, as it turns out, a pretty good twin slam card if you have strength gen
it's a walker claw with extra control and a bonus doubled gem
i love onyx
same
the twin slam twin slams my man
because i can just slap it on a card with temp stats and boom free dex

messages.content: 4 commons, 3 uncommons, 2 rares
…Wait, is that really all of them?

Anyway, 36 copies of Twin Slam if order does not matter; 72 if order doees matter.
Plus a Future Plans+.
sapphire for brace, amethyst for piercing wail, aquamarine for ward
there's 12 gems so if order doesn't matter thats (12+1) * (12/2) = 78, but if order does matter then it's 144
anyways 33/78 or 63/144 twin slams would have some form of defense in them, which is pretty significant
Okay if order doesn't matter then put onyx first
do it

I pretty much always socket my starting gem and upgrade this at first campfire. Citrine and quartz into this is a beautiful dream but you can't really afford to keep it empty until your first rare, it carries you through act 1 reasonably well. Very occasionally you'll get that super OP Guardian transform/pry/socket event and get to quartz/citrine it anyways and win the run.
This with citrine is just too much tbh

messages.content: Okay, thank you. I do want to see how this could work, though.

All of those full Twin Slam+ cards and one Future Sight.
This combined with the "Normal enemies give relics instead of cards" modifier could be bonkers.

common: str, dex, thorns, brace
uncommon: draw, accel, ward, shiv, vuln, piercing wail
rare: energy, debuff down
ah I remember seeing a row of 4, a row of 3, and a row of 2 in the thumbnail (literally what I was mentally referencing)
but there was 2 rows of 3
order only really matters for onyx tbh
and only for ruby emerald tourmaline
or a slam with 2 of either aqua, draw, accelerate or shiv and a nearly full hand
deceptive pyramid :runic_pyramid:

Curl up is a pretty miserable first upgrade, and with the recent changes to key breaks, red key start is essentially gone. That means you're likely starting with twin slam upgraded (you might have taken a card from the heart bonus, which could be a better upgrade). The upgrade is very solid on twin slam, letting it carry the early game pretty effectively, and letting you get double the value from the gems it holds. It can have some very strong gem combos, as already mentioned by other posters, but due to the nature of act 1 (needing to draw frontloaded damage cards, skills being bad against nob, low impact cards being bad against tri-sentries) you will likely need to socket your starting gem into twin slam to smooth out your draws. Makes starting with sapphire feel even worse, but there are some builds that can use the double brace to consistently enter defensive mode for value.

Upgraded, it will deal 14 damage for 2 (or 7 for 1), which should be very useful to get through the early game, but will definitely still need help to take on the elites. If you are lucky enough to be able to start with ruby/emerald, and be able to wait for an onyx, this can be a viable part of your late game scaling. In most cases, it will more typically be an efficient value play, as doubling up on two gems is really powerful, especially with quartz, amber, onyx, citrine, and amethyst. Twin slam often ends up as a good target for looping with reroute/recover for value. A twin slam with a particularly strong combo might even be worth using dolly's mirror on.

It gets better once you have the 4th energy, as two of the gems you are likely to have, and one possible pickup (ruby, emerald, garnet) are more impactful when you can play more cards after them in the same turn. Can be really good with runic pyramid if you end up with debuff cards to pair with ruby/emerald.  Having twin slam as a starter (and the possibility of fragmented gem) also makes all the ninja relics strong on guardian.
Very good analysis!
here's a save file for the Every Twin Slam Gem Combo run so you don't have to do all the socketing yourself
